Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Carson J. Bruns of Northwestern University to conduct a research project in Math and Physical Sciences during the summer of 2013 at the University of Tokyo in Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, Japan. The project title is "Programming Simple Molecules to Self-Assemble into Well-Defined Nanoparticles with Intricate Hierarchical Architectures." The host scientist is Professor Makoto Fujita.

The 'bottom-up' strategies to nanotechnology, which carry the banners of self-assembly, supramolecular chemistry, and molecular nanotechnology, are often highly sensitive to experimental conditions or limited by serendipitous discovery. Scientific breakthroughs in this field will be marked by research that describes ways to self-assemble increasingly intricate nano-objects in a more rational, predictable, robust, and well-defined manner. Toward this end, the award supports the development of self-assembled metallo-organic molecular nanoparticles known as M12L24 spheres (where M is a metal ion and L is an organic ligand) to serve as a platform around which to orchestrate the hierarchical self-assembly of more complex molecular architectures. This goal is realized by installing functional groups on the ligands that have the capacity for molecular recognition, which allow them to participate in multiple compatible modes of self-assembly that span a spectrum of strengths and length scales, and include the self-assembly of 'molecular machine' prototypes such as mechanically interlocked molecules known as catenanes, rotaxanes, and pseudorotaxanes.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, the Fellow disseminates and enhances scientific understanding to a broad audience by sharing the EAPSI experience at international research conferences and at collaborating national laboratories in both Japan and the United States. The Fellow will extend the benefits of this international research experience to younger students by mentoring undergraduates in related research at the host institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. Molecular self-assembly is the process by which a pool of disordered molecules spontaneously evolves, by virtue of weak local noncovalent interactions, into collections of molecules with more ordered superstructures. The magnificent and complex molecular structures that underpin cell biology (e.g. proteins, DNA) can be described as Nature’s champions of self-assembly, as they express a rich and diverse library of highly functional self-assembled architectures. Our ability to understand, mimic, and harness self-assembly is paramount to the development of new revolutionary nanotechnologies that advance the frontiers of contemporary science. One intriguing application of self-assembly is the possibility of constructing ‘molecular flasks’ – reaction vessels that contain only a small, well-defined number of chemicals. Molecular flasks can dramatically alter the properties and reactivities of the molecules they contain, since they both exist on similar size scales. In this Project, the recent development of relatively large molecular flasks, known as M12L24 spheres, was leveraged to explore, for the first time, a supramolecular host-guest complex within the confined nanospace of a molecular flask. The electrostatic and steric constraints of the flask did indeed affect the properties of the analyte. Remarkably, it was discovered that the outer shell of the molecular flask acts as a gate – reminiscent of transmembrane ion channels in biology – which can be opened and closed in response to changes in the ionic strength of the solution. The nanoscopic molecular flask can effectively be 'opened' and 'closed' by an experimentalist, which is a result of a synergistic overlap of intrinsic properties of the flask and the host-guest complex under study. Neither the host-guest complex nor the molecular flask that was built to contain it express this stimulus-responsive property independently of the other. Thus it was demonstrated that molecular flasks can increase the sophistication, complexity, and stimulus-responsiveness of an otherwise simple supramolecular complex. These encouraging results will motivate future work on the development of molecular flasks for uncovering emergent properties in chemical systems and ultimately developing new nanotechnologies.

Broader Impacts. The international research experience for the PI and collaborators, which includes an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the hosting country (Japan), as well as to the societal and cultural traditions, are broader impacts that affect the personal and professional development of several young scientists involved in the project.  This aspect of the Project meets the NSF goal to educate early-career citizens in international collaborations, promoting global awareness in the scientific workforce. The project has also enhanced research infrastructure by integrating human and physical resources into the network of US collaborations, strengthening international partnerships and enabling better access to state-of-the-art instrumentation that is not widely available in the US. As a first-generation student of higher education, the Fellow’s activities amount to broadened participation of underrepresented groups. The Fellow’s activities as a mentor to undergraduate students extend the benefits of the Project into the US education system to promote teaching, training, and learning through hands-on research experience and international networking.
